text.author: Paul Flowers, Edward J. Neth, William R. Robinson, Klaus Theopold, Richard Langley
text.title: Chemistry: Atoms First 2e
text.summary: This textbook excerpt goes over the history of the concept of atoms in chemistry, including Ancient Greek views and Dalton's Atomic Theory, which stipulates that all matter is made of atoms, which are the smallest units of matter and belong to distinct element types, which are neither created nor destroyed in the course of chemical reactions.
text.summary2: This section of a textbook describes postulates of John Dalton’s 1807 atomic theory: matter is composed of atoms, each element consists of only one type of atom, atoms of one element are different from atoms of all other elements, compounds are made of atoms of two or more elements in whole number ratios, and atoms are neither created nor destroyed during a chemical change.

figure.rend: three pairs of orbs, two green and one blue, labeled ‘starting materials’, are joined by plus signs, and an arrow points to two sets of alternating green/blue/green orbs, joined by a plus and labeled ‘products of the change’.
